luminosity_quiz.title: Understanding Luminosity
luminosity_quiz.question: You selected a luminosity of **{lumi} fb⁻¹**. But what does integrated luminosity actually represent in a particle physics experiment?
options: The amount of time the detector is active
The number of collisions per second
The total number of collisions over a period of time
The energy at which the collisions happen

feedback.0: Correct! Luminosity represents the total number of collisions in the dataset. The more luminosity, the better chance of seeing rare events like the Higgs boson.
feedback.1: Incorrect. Try again or read more about luminosity!

lepton_selection_quiz.title: Lepton Final State
lepton_selection_quiz.question: What can the number of leptons indicate?
options: Two leptons indicate a simple decay of a neutral particle, like a Z boson
Four leptons indicate a more complex decay chain, possibly involving a Higgs boson
An odd number of leptons suggests an exotic process
All of the above

feedback.0: Correct! Each option represents a possibility based on your selection.
feedback.1: Incorrect. Try thinking about how leptons are produced in pairs.

charge_selection_quiz.title: Understanding Charge Selection
charge_selection_quiz.question: You selected lepton pairs with **{charge} charge**. Why is the charge of lepton pairs important in particle physics?
options: Charge conservation is a fundamental principle, and decay products should conserve the charge
Leptons with the same charge are more common in particle decays like the Z boson decay
Charge doesn't play a significant role in particle interactions
Same-charge lepton pairs indicate a high-energy collision

feedback.0: Correct! Charge conservation is fundamental in particle physics, and opposite-charge leptons are typical in decays like the Z boson decay.
feedback.1: Incorrect. Consider how charge conservation works in decays. Opposite-charge leptons are expected in many standard decays.

pt_cut_quiz.title: Choosing Appropriate Cuts for Lepton p$_T$
pt_cut_quiz.question: Based on what we’ve discussed, which of the following cut values would help us focus on Higgs-like events by reducing the background?
options: No cuts are necessary

feedback.0: Correct! Setting cuts of 20, 15, and 10 on the lepton p$_T$ values can help us focus on Higgs-like events by filtering out background.
feedback.1: Not quite. Focus on values that effectively reduce background noise while keeping the majority of the signal.

invariant_mass_selection_quiz.title: Invariant Mass
invariant_mass_selection_quiz.question: The invariant mass is a crucial quantity in particle physics. What can it tell us about a particle?
options: The energy of the particle
The momentum of the particle
The rest mass of the particle that produced the leptons
The type of particle that decayed

feedback.0: Correct! The invariant mass tells us the mass of the particle that decayed into the leptons.
feedback.1: Incorrect. Remember, invariant mass relates to the particle's rest mass.

invariant_mass_Z.title: Interpreting the Invariant Mass Plot
invariant_mass_Z.question: You generated an invariant mass plot. If a peak appears around 91 GeV, which particle might it correspond to?
options: Higgs boson
Z boson
Photon
Top quark

feedback.0: Correct! A peak around 91 GeV typically corresponds to the Z boson.
feedback.1: Incorrect. Peaks near 91 GeV usually indicate the presence of a Z boson, since 91 GeV is its mass.

data_only_plot_quiz.question: What do you observe in the data-only plot?
options: A clear peak
Some fluctuations, but it's hard to tell
No specific features

feedback.1: Exactly! Without context, it’s hard to tell which fluctuations might be a signal.
feedback.0: Are you looking at the Higgs already? Let's continue to see if you got it.

background_simulation_quiz.question: With the background simulation, do you notice any additional peaks?
options: Yes, there seems to be an extra peak
No, it all looks like background
Not sure

feedback.0: Good observation! We may be seeing something beyond the background alone.

simulated_higgs_signal_quiz.question: With the simulated Higgs signal added, what do you conclude?
options: There’s a peak matching the Higgs signal
Still unclear
Background fits the data better

feedback.0: That's right! The alignment of the peak with the simulated Higgs signal provides evidence that we have indeed observed the Higgs boson.
